match.series: Sri Lanka tour of New Zealand, 2014-15

commentary.line: So, that's all we have for you from this game. Both teams will now lock horns on Friday at Dunedin. Remember, it is a day game and we hope to see you then. Until next time, take care.

Kane Williamson: I had a few days off which was nice. Just relaxed and caught up with my family and friends. Just wanted the shoulder to heal. It was nice to get off to a reasonable start. It is always nice to bat with other guys who are scoring freely. It was great initially with Elliott, before Anderson took over. Ronchi was just superb to finish it off the way he did. I am still very much working on my bowling and I am pretty happy with how it is progressing.
Kane Williamson is the Man of the Match for his knock of 103.

Brendon McCullum: Really good effort from the bowlers to restrict them under 300. Williamson showed how experienced he is in formulating a gameplan. Also, Anderson and Ronchi finished it off in the end. There was probably a little bit more bounce here at the Oval. Pace was definitely there in comparison to last year. The crowd was really great. We don't know yet about Adam Milne (talking about his injured rib). The great thing about this team is that someone else will step up in case anything goes wrong. I will try to lead by example as they expect us to fight hard. Elliott had a tough time of late, but he showed strength of character and was one of the assets the selectors were keen to see. He is a great team man, and is a classy batsman at club level. The partnership he formed with Kane was crucial to getting us into this. Williamson has been wonderful and it's great to see him work his magic.

Angelo Mathews: After the start we got, I thought the lower order batted poorly. I thought Dilshan, Sangakkara and Mahela batted beautifully. It was a very good wicket but it didn't turn as much. It was a good batting track. We had to put pressure on the batsmen, but Kane batted brilliantly. The spinners have been bowling brilliantly, the wicket didn't get slow, but the spinners bowled well. We couldn't strike regularly.
Time for the presentation ceremony
Tim Southee was the pick of the bowlers for New Zealand, taking 3/59 in his 10 overs. Both Milne and McClenaghan gave him good company as well, picking two wickets each.

After Sanga got out and Mathews followed him back to the pavilion a ball later, Jayawardene decided to take the attack to the opposition. He helped Sri Lanka go past 250, but after he got out just 6 short of his century, the Sri Lankan innings crumbled while trying to up the ante.

In the first innings, Sri Lanka started poorly as Karunaratne was out very early, but Dilshan and Sangakkara then put on a 100-plus partnership to steady the innings. Dilshan fell after that and Sangakkara was joined by Jayawardene, who looked in superb touch, but both failed to reach their hundreds. Sangakkara got out on 76 and during his innings, he went past Sanath Jayasuriya to become the third highest run-scorer in ODIs.
The Sri Lankan bowlers weren't upto the mark and after taking three wickets early, they couldn't capitalize on the advantage.

Along with Elliott, Williamson put on a 88-run stand for the 4th wicket and helped New Zealand get closer to the total. After Elliott departed for 44, Anderson came to the crease and both Williamson and Anderson started accelerating, they put on a 79-run stand for the 5th wicket before Williamson departed. Anderson fell soon after and Ronchi, who had joined him at the crease after Williamson's wicket, finished things off in style for the home team. Ronchi's 32 runs off 15 balls meant that New Zealand won with 11 balls to spare.

This is a great victory for New Zealand after they got off to a poor start, losing Brendon McCullum in the 5th over. Guptill and Taylor also failed to get going and at one stage, the Black Caps were reeling at 63/3. However, Kane Williamson, playing his second game of the tournament, had other plans in his mind. He was brilliant with the bat, notching up his 5th ODI ton.
New Zealand take a 2-1 lead in the series. Ronchi and Vettori are extremely happy as they walk off the field. The players congratulate each other and shake hands.

45.4   T Perera to Ronchi, out Corey Anderson Run Out!! Anderson is run-out here. It was full toss on the pads, Ronchi can't put it away fine. There was a loud appeal as the ball hits the pad, but the umpire turns it down. The batsmen go through in search of a single as the ball rolls away towards Dilshan at backward point. There was some confusion in running between the wickets and Anderson stopped in the middle of the pitch, while Dilshan quickly runs in, picks the ball and throws at the striker's end, a direct-hit catches him short. This is another big break for the Lankans. Corey Anderson run out (Dilshan) 47(44) [4s-2 6s-2]
T Perera to Ronchi, THATS OUT!! Run Out!!

Meanwhile, he exposes his leg stump and misses the ball completely, the ball crashes into the leg stump. End of an outstanding innings from Williamson. Williamson b T Perera 103(107) [4s-6 6s-1]

Jayawardene then stabilized the innings with Thirimanne, putting on 65 runs for the 5th wicket before Thirimanne departed. Jaywardene also perished soon after while trying to accelerate the scoring, falling short of a ton by 6 runs. At the end, Sri Lanka folded for 276 and the Black Caps need 277 runs to take a 2-1 lead in the series. The run-chase starts in a short while from now. Stay tuned.

Earlier, Sri Lanka got off to a poor start, losing opener Karunaratne when the team score was just 11. Dilshan and Sangakkara then steadied the innings with a 102-run stand, increasing the run-rate in the process as well. After Dilshan got out, Sanga was joined by Jayawardene at the crease, who was in sublime touch. Sanga, in the meanwhile, became the third highest run-scorer in ODIs, going past Sanath Jayasuriya. Both batsmen batted well, but Sangakkara got out in the 34th over. Mathews then came to the crease and was out the next ball as well.

New Zealand must be delighted with how they pulled things back in the last few overs. At one stage, when Sangakkara and Jayawardene were batting, Sri Lanka looked all set to achieve a total in excess of 300, but the Black Caps bowlers bowled really well towards the end. Southee was the pick of the bowlers, taking 3 wickets and he was well supported by Milne and McClenaghan, who picked up 2 wickets each.

Teams:

Sri Lanka (Playing XI): Dimuth Karunaratne, Tillakaratne Dilshan, Kumar Sangakkara(w), Mahela Jayawardene, Angelo Mathews(c), Lahiru Thirimanne, Thisara Perera, Jeevan Mendis, Nuwan Kulasekara, Sachithra Senanayake, Rangana Herath

New Zealand (Playing XI): Brendon McCullum(c), Martin Guptill, Kane Williamson, Ross Taylor, Grant Elliott, Corey Anderson, Luke Ronchi(w), Daniel Vettori, Tim Southee, Mitchell McClenaghan, Adam Milne
New Zealand have made 3 changes - Williamson, Elliott and Milne come in place of Latham, Nathan McCullum and Henry.
Sri Lanka have won the toss and have opted to bat

The Sri Lankan bowlers have done well from time to time, but they still lack consistency. Bowling against batsmen like Brendon McCullum is no easy task, but they need to focus more on the right line and lengths. Herath, Senanayake and Dilshan have bowled well, but need the same kind of support from their pacers. It should be a cracker of a contest. Toss and teams coming up in a short while. Stay tuned.

For Sri Lanka, Dilshan's century in the second ODI showed that they are up for a fight. His ton helped Sri Lanka win their first game on the tour. With the likes of Sangakkara, Jayawardene and Mathews in the team, Sri Lankan batting looks very solid. However, they will be up against the likes of Southee, Milne and McClenaghan. The Kiwi bowlers have bowled good line and lengths, making life difficult for the visitors.

The Black Caps will be a little worried about Ross Taylor's current form as he hasn't looked confident with the bat. Grant Elliott is all set to make a return to the team, with Latham expected to sit this game out, in accordance with New Zealand's rotation policy. The Kiwis will also take a late call on whether Kane Williamson is fit to play this ODI or not.

After the third ODI got washed out, the 7-match series has now effectively become a 6-game series. With both teams tied at 1-1, today's game is going to be very important for both the teams. Hello and welcome to the fourth ODI between New Zealand and Sri Lanka.

Preview

Overview:

The seven-match series moves to the north-west of New Zealand, to the city of Nelson, with the teams level at 1-1. The recent performances of Brendon McCullum's men have slowly improved their World Cup stocks from 'dark horses' to 'possible semi-finalists'. A win in Nelson tomorrow will not only reinforce their current standing in World cricket but also give them a crucial lead in the tune-up series. That holds true for Sri Lanka, too. After an indifferent performance in the first ODI, they put up a far better show in Hamilton. A win in Nelson, will mark a good turnaround of fortunes after the drubbing in the Test series.

New Zealand:

Brendon McCullum has stood head and shoulders above his mates in terms of performances. His blitz in the first ODI was followed by an equally entertaining century in the second. Much of the team's fortunes hinges on how McCullum goes at the top of the order. That isn't to say that New Zealand is a one-man team. In fact, their pace bowling combination of Trent Boult, Adam Milne and Mitchell McClenaghan have been thoroughly impressive. The middle-order's competence against quality spin remains an area of concern. Ross Taylor, after being rested for the opening encounter, has struggled to get going. Ditto for Tom Latham despite a dogged 42 in the abandoned third ODI. Grant Elliott will take his place in the middle-order and New Zealand will take a late call on Kane Williamson's fitness.

Sri Lanka:

Sri Lanka fought back well after the defeat in Christchurch. Tillakaratne Dilshan's century in Hamilton gave them a much needed win on the tour. With Mahela Jayawardene, Kumar Sangakkara and Angelo Mathews around, the batting still looks capable. They will however, be vary of Lahiru Thirimanne's no-show. While their pacers have gone for plenty in the face of McCullum's onslaughts, the return of Rangana Herath and his combination with Sachithra Senanayake holds Sri Lanka in good stead. Dilshan meanwhile has emerged as a capable bowling option for Mathews and could prompt the skipper to play an extra seamer.

Pitch and Conditions:

In a stark contrast to the weather in Auckland, Nelson is expected to be bright and sunny.

Stats and Trivia:

Kumar Sangakkara is 17-runs shy of overtaking Sanath Jayasuriya and becoming Sri Lanka's top run-getter in ODI history.
Teams:

Sri Lanka (From): Dimuth Karunaratne, Tillakaratne Dilshan, Kumar Sangakkara(w), Mahela Jayawardene, Angelo Mathews(c), Lahiru Thirimanne, Thisara Perera, Jeevan Mendis, Sachithra Senanayake, Nuwan Kulasekara, Suranga Lakmal, Dinesh Chandimal, Shaminda Eranga, Rangana Herath, Dhammika Prasad, Lasith Malinga

New Zealand (From): Martin Guptill, Brendon McCullum(c), Tom Latham, Ross Taylor, Grant Elliott, Corey Anderson, Luke Ronchi(w), Nathan McCullum, Tim Southee, Mitchell McClenaghan, Matt Henry, Daniel Vettori, Kane Williamson, Adam Milne, Kyle Mills, Trent Boult
